You have the wrong Charter section and are entirely missing the point. You are referring to s. 10(b). The section applicable in this case is 11(b) "Any person charged with an offence has the right: (b) to be tried within a reasonable time". 

In this case, Curtis's lawyer is not available at an early date, and so Curtis is deemed to have waived his right to a prompt trial. However, co-accused's Corey's lawyer is available and ready to proceed promptly. The crown insists on trying the two together. The question that arises is whether Curtis's waiver of the Jordan time limit can be applied to Corey.

The obvious answer is to sever the indictment and proceed promptly to try Corey, and try Curtis separately when his lawyer is available.

 I eat meat, alas. I went through a short period when I ate only meat from game that I killed, back in the South. It's just about the only truly ethical meat that you can eat. I say "just about" because a friend of mine runs an organic hog farm, in Missouri, where every process and protocol is a rejection of industrialized meat production.

The term "runaway warming" or "runaway GHE" has a specific definition in climate science. For Earth, it would require about 80 additional W/m² of solar irradiance, bringing it to the K-I limit, boiling off all of the oceans while decoupling the Planck response, resulting in a surface temperature near that of Venus. No, you have not constantly heard this.

GCM projections have very successfully simulated a variety of future and past climate conditions.

Consensus reflects the state of knowledge of the scientific community. It is very much a part of science.

Speaking of which, again, the consensus "best" estimate of ECS is 3ºC. (1.8 for TCR). Feedbacks supporting those values are clearly evident in simple calculations comparing forcing and temperature increase in the record. And, of course, glacials and interglacials in paleoclimate would not have been possible without those feedbacks.

Historically, human civilization has likely not seen global temperature as high as now.

When my mother developed terminal cancer at age 84, she had 2 grown sons and one widower son-in-law.

Her wish was to "die in her own bed" and this she did. My brother, brother-in-law and I arranged to look after her every evening from 5 pm through to 9 am. The province provided day "nursing" (not with an RN) during the work week. The oncologist came down a couple of times a week from the hospital to check on her condition.

Obviously, care in one's own home is far less expensive on the medicare system than spending $1000s a day on hospital-care. And, just as obviously, my mother was far happier spending her final days in her own home.

Years later, my daughter and I  tried to offer the same type of care to my mother's 97 year old cousin.

While this happened 20 years ago, the care we tried to give my mother was very much in line with what Dr. Picard advocates.

Logging does not stop wildfire. There are more than enough fuels to carry fire whether they are logged or not. In fact, there are many ways in which logging makes fires wore. 1) Logging roads provide access for people who start fires, whether intentionally or unintentionally. 2) Removing the forest canopy generates a lot of hazardous logging slash, and makes the forest hotter, dyer, and windier, all factors that makes fuel and fires worse. 3) Removing the canopy also stimulates the growth of shrubs and small trees that act as "ladder fuels" and carry fires into the forest canopy.  4) Young trees farms are far more flammable than mature native forests. Tree farms have dense homogeneous fuels close to the ground where they are most at risk from surface fires. Mature forests have more complex heterogeneous pattern of fuels, so fire is less likely to carry far and fast. Mature forests also help maintain cool/moist conditions that help moderate fires.

Many states have had sales taxes for a long time and have relatively effective ways to deal with this, we just need to look at them. I am sure localities like Juneau have limited ability to enforce and mechanisms to collect but it becomes a different beast at the state level.

Thanks to California and Amazon, a state can now tax sales even if the business does not have a physical presence in the state. That means we're not going to get around a sales tax by purchasing something on the internet anymore, sorry. This is a common concern local businesses bring up about sales tax but this excuse is history.

Also states levy sales tax on items purchased in other states and brought in. If it comes from a state with no sales tax you would pay the full tax; if purchased in a state with a sales tax you would pay the difference. So you're not going to buy a car in another state and bring it here to escape taxes. Could you? I suppose but you would be taking a big risk since it would be illegal.

Ozy, your argument is incorrectly applied here. 
First off, there are 1-2 forms of random with the lottery. 
When you pick numbers, then your ticket is no longer random, but the draw IS. 
OTOH, if you take a quick pick, then both the ticket, along with the draw, are random. 
This guy took a quick pick. As such, randomness was still happening. 
He should get the winnings. 

OTOH, there is a guy that won AFTER one of the dates. His argument is that had these guys not fixed the numbers, that his winnings would have included the previous amounts. 
However, that is NOT necessarily true. The fact is, that it was possible to actually pull those same numbers. So, in his case, he should NOT get another penny.

However, the issue about getting money back for the ticket is going to be a thorny one. You have to prove, which means that you must have the original ticket. 
If they have it, I say, give them their money back. But, this one is a totally different issue.

Interesting viewpoint and an informed speaker.

However debt-GDP ratios can not be looked in isolation.

Borrowings used to purchase infrastructure that provides future benefits -- could be reasonable IF the intention was to generate sufficient funds to retire the debt at the end of the respective useful life of the infrastructure asset.

However borrowing to finance operational costs (deficits) today - generate an intergenerational transfer of the bill to future generations.  

It is easy to run up the government's debt on operational charges.  The government of the day is likely to be popular (the joys of the free lunch)

However, the running up of the credit card can impact the government's debt rating.  Credit downgrades increase future borrowing costs.   Also, while interest rates are low now, when that debt comes due, interest rates will probably rise.

It's way too early to say what Taggart will accomplish in recruiting as Oregon's new head football coach. But he is definitely taking a very different approach from that of Helfrich or Kelly. Taggart seems more hands on, and more aware of how to use social media to connect to and establish rapport with recruits. By contrast, Helfrich and Kelly seemed more "traditional", but over time, especially in the last few seasons, that approach wasn't working as well anymore.

As for recruiting QBs specifically, I think Taggart has a good track record. When he was the running backs coach under Jim Harbaugh at Stanford, he helped to recruit Andrew Luck, who was a pro-style QB. At his last stop, University of South Florida, Taggart recruited and developed Quinton Flowers into a dual-threat QB running a prolific offense. The most obvious need for Ducks recruiting is defense. Taggart needs more defensive play-makers, like Jabril Peppers of Michigan and Jonathan Allen of Alabama... holiday wish list!

For several years in Sitka, Ak-DOT has been planning a $16 million, 9-mile single lane gravel road to Katlian Bay. The project persists despite its original purpose and need - to access rock and gravel - being infeasible because a multi-span bridge would be needed. Instead, the plan now is to reroute the road to access a new trailhead for a trail the Forest Service would presumably  create. The road project has never stood on its own legs -- it is funded through a state ballot bond measure that included other projects.

Ak-DOT is nearly done with an appx. 500 page impact statement for the project, planned for July. However, Ak-DOT will not accept or consider public comments on the EIS. The whole process is a sham; appropriated dollars chasing a purpose, not planning based on reason or government of, by and for the people. 

The $14 million still left in the Katlian project pot should revert to the state budget or pay-down Sitka's hydropower project.

The issue for public schools, the Post Office, and other government-mandated monopolies is that they are not incentivized to be innovative and save costs, and don't run as a business should.  For example, when you say "fully funded," what does that mean?  ASD says "our programs will cost x," and we respond "Ok, here you go?"  Superintendents, like Post Masters, are not given the power to hire and promote good performers, while firing bad performers, and the ASD does not educate the public about what their goals are.  "Graduation" is not a goal.  They should instead be stating the following: "When a student is in ASD, they will be provided the following services."  and, "If (not when) a student graduates, they will be equipped to do the following...."  If they stated and listed those goals more clearly and openly, I think the public might find many programs to be unnecessary, and would force ASD to actually practice the innovations it says it engenders.

Along with major reductions in the energy sector, we need to fundamentally change the way we grow and raise food. If land use, transportation, methane emissions, carbon released from soil, and fertilizer use are all factored in, between 40 and 57% of GHG emissions are related to the agricultural sector (which also uses 85% of fresh water). In fact, soil is the largest land-based carbon sink, but industrial farming methods have turned soil into a net carbon emitter. "He had been the first Territorial Governor of Oregon (after Lincoln declined) "
No Mr. Walsh,   Lincoln did not "decline" the position of first Territorial Governor  of Oregon.   In 1848  Lane, a D,  was appointed Territorial Governor  by Democratic President Polk who would never have dreamed  of appointing Lincoln, a Whig.  Later Lincoln  campaigned heavily for the Whig  presidential candidate Gen. Zachary Taylor with the hope he'd be appointed  head  of the Government Land Office.
While Taylor won, he only proposed Lincoln as Oregon's Secretary of State, which he declined; Taylor then offered the  territorial governor's position but Lincoln declined that also.  Taylor then in 1850  appointed a fellow Whig, John Gaines, who proved to be rather unpopular in this largely Democratic state.
Why did Lincoln reject Taylor's offer  to be our second Territorial Governor?  Possibly because he'd have no political future in a largely D state, or  because Mary didn't want to "Go  way out West."

Re: "Weapons that remove meaningful human control from target-and-kill decisions sit on the wrong side of a clear moral line" confuses several issues.  First, it assumes that human control will mean "target-and-kill" decisions will be made morally, but programmed decisions (guided by software) by definition will be indiscriminate.  This is not the case at all - human control can lead to directly to immoral killing (e.g. killing non-combatants), and, equally, software developers can do their best to distinguish combatants from others, err on the side of protecting civilians, etc.

If the argument is that humans will outperform autonomous robots in protecting non-combatants, that is speculative.  The number of non-combatant and "friendly fire" casualties in combat is shockingly high - it is a pretty low bar that the robots will have to clear. 

Like self-driving cars, builders don't need to prove that the car will never make a driving mistake, just that they will make fewer than humans.

I have always loved Whittier.  I had a Tollycraft moored in Whittier from 1983 to 1990, finally residing in slip C-5.  How  well I remember the fun days, despite the rain.  We rode the train to Whittier in a box car with our legs hanging out the door.  We looked forward to eating deep fried halibut at the Anchor Inn and playing pool in the Buckner building in the evening.  I did a lot of fishing and shrimping in PW Sound, once hitting a rock and losing a propeller.   We explored everywhere in the western Sound.   In 1989, I got a contract with VECO to bed and board a beach clean-up crew after the Exxon oil spill.  Unfortunately in 1990, my job forced me to leave Alaska.  My Tollycraft was strapped to a rail car and rolled onto a barge for shipment to San Diego.  But, I still have my memories and my pictures of the most wonderful experiences that life could bring to anyone.  I will always treasure them.

Experience teaches that I should include some qualifiers with respect to the previously-given death-toll inflicted by invasive felines, because some nitwit with a lot of emotion but no science will make specious objections if I don't.  The horrific destruction will of course vary regionally and according to prey availability.  For example, I live in Alaska.  We have no reptiles, so I wouldn't expect free-roaming cats to be killing them.  Similarly, Florida is overrun with exotic reptiles thanks to the pet trade--to where there are now twice as many exotic reptiles established there as there are native reptile species.  So one would expect exotic reptiles to figure more prominently in the kill-counts.  Doesn't help the native green anole (Anolis carolinensis), which is one of the most frequently cat-killed species.  Nor does it affect the Alaskan kill-count in terms of numbers.  No reptiles means there will simply be more native mammals and birds among the slaughtered.

Proportional representation could be a solution to our democracy's corrupting, despotic concentration of power. Political writers have perceived the limits of power any person or body can have to be the foundation of a free society. I was introduced to the importance of the limits to power in Montesquieu's The Spirit of the Laws and later in the political writings of writers like John Locke.

First past the post is a system that can give established political parties majorities, with near absolute power, with a little over one third of the popular vote. We must also consider the other side of the equation. New parties, which can be a response to abuses by established parties, can get over ten percent of the popular vote and win no seats. First past the post shuts out new political movements, giving established parties a despotic stranglehold on power.

Alaskans who purchase insurance through the ACA marketplace (including my wife and me) are hit with a double-whammy: 1. Health care costs in Alaska are very high, and 2. The risk pool over which these costs are spread is very small. This bill is good in that it spreads the high costs that some patients incur over a larger population.  However, it would be even better if the 23,000 or so patients in the ACA market could join larger pools.  Remember, the way you drive down medical costs is by combining as many patients as possible into one single pool, and then that pool of patients will have more bargaining power when negotiating cost of care from physicians, medical centers, pharmaceutical firms, etc.  Almost every other developed nation has single payer plans like that, and that is why their health care is so much less expensive and of equal or better quality than here.

"Aside from a $50 per term co-pay, none of those students has to pay a dime in tuition this year, unless they choose to take more than 12 credits a term."

This is simply untrue.  At Portland Community College, tuition this year is $97 per credit.  For a student taking 12 credits, that is $1164 in tuition and maximum Oregon Promise grant is only $1132 per term.  Subtract the $50 copay and tack on at least another $100 in mandatory fees by the college, the student is coming up approximately $182 short per term, not including books.

For a student taking 8 credits, the grant is cut in half.  Tuition would be $776 and the grant only $566.  Again, subtract the $50 copay and tack on at least another $74 in mandatory fees by the college, the student is coming up approximately $334 short per term, not including books.
